title-group.article-title: Time‐course manganese chloride biodistribution and manganese‐induced MRI contrast in mouse organs

sec.title: Purpose
sec.p: To optimize manganese‐enhanced MRI (MEMRI) in mice by profiling the time‐course biodistribution and associated T1 contrast enhancement of MnCl2 injected subcutaneously to avoid abrupt spikes in blood manganese levels.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Manganese (Mn) biodistribution and Mn‐induced T1 contrast in healthy female adult CD‐1 mice were investigated at two doses (0.2 and 0.4 mmol/kg) and 2, 6, and 24 h following injection. T1‐weighted MRI and T1 mapping were performed at 3 T. The heart, liver, kidneys, leg skeletal muscle, lungs, spleen, and blood were collected and quantified for Mn content using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy. Toxicity was assessed on hematoxylin and eosin histological sections of the heart, liver, kidneys, lungs, and spleen.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: An injection dose of 0.2 mmol/kg produced significant T1 enhancement in the heart, liver, and kidneys, reaching peak enhancement at 2 h following injection. Doubling the dose did not produce further T1 enhancement in the heart, liver, nor kidneys. Skeletal muscle reached peak enhancement at 24 h and required an injection dose of 0.4 mmol/kg. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy–measured tissue‐level Mn content corroborated MRI results and revealed peak Mn concentration also at 2 h following injection in the spleen, lungs, and blood. No organ toxicity was observed at either dose on histology.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The subcutaneous injection route provided substantial T1 contrast enhancement in all tissues investigated, without toxicity at the maximum dose of 0.4 mmol/kg tested. However, the injection dose and optimal postinjection imaging interval must be tailored to the organ of interest.

institution-wrap.institution: Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada

p.mixed-citation: ZhuangK, VollettKDW, HouM, ChangY, ChengH‐LM. Time‐course manganese chloride biodistribution and manganese‐induced MRI contrast in mouse organs. Magn Reson Med. 2025;94:1227‐1236. doi: 10.1002/mrm.30522PMC1220272040189753

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Manganese(II) (Mn) is a paramagnetic ion capable of enhancing the contrast of anatomical structures on T1‐weighted MRI, 1 , 2 similar to widely deployed gadolinium(III) (Gd)–based contrast agents. Unlike Gd, which must be chelated for safety, Mn is an endogenous and essential trace mineral involved in regulating biological processes and metabolic pathways. 3 For this reason, Mn is significantly less toxic than Gd and can be administered at low doses in its ionic form. 4 As an ion—more specifically, a calcium ion analog—Mn can cross the cell membrane, such as via voltage‐dependent calcium (Ca2+) channels, 5 to provide not only anatomical but also functional information on MRI. For over 40 years, manganese‐enhanced MRI (MEMRI) has been exploited extensively in studying brain structure, 6 , 7 neural activity, 8 , 9 and myocardial viability. 10 , 11 More recently, MEMRI demonstrated the ability to detect and characterize tumors where Gd‐enhanced MRI could not, 12 , 13 , 14 possibly revealing Ca2+‐related mechanisms in proliferating cancer cells. 15 MEMRI has also been shown effective in in vivo tracking of genetically engineered human stem cells. 16 , 17 Despite the value and potential of MEMRI, however, its exploration beyond the brain and heart is much more limited, and guidelines on Mn administration for body MEMRI are scant.

Exogenous Mn is typically administered by injecting or ingesting a MnCl2 solution. To ensure safety, the dose of Mn must be carefully controlled, as overexposure to Mn can induce acute and chronic toxicity, including cardiovascular toxicity, neurodegenerative disorders, and hepatotoxicity. 3 , 18 , 19 The administration route must also be factored into safety considerations. For instance, most MEMRI studies inject Mn intravenously to achieve rapid distribution, but this is also the riskiest route due to potential acute cardiovascular toxicity from a sudden spike in blood Mn levels. 20 Intraperitoneal and subcutaneous injections are less toxic, but the associated slower distribution and accumulation of Mn may result in insufficient contrast if Mn is eliminated from the body more rapidly than its accumulation in tissue. Abundant literature exists in the brain on MEMRI of neuronal architecture and function, contrast efficiency for different injection routes and doses, and in vivo Mn biodistribution. 21 , 22 , 23 , 24 , 25 , 26 , 27 , 28 , 29 Similar studies in the heart can also be found. 30 , 31 , 32 Outside of the brain and heart, however, very few studies have been carried out. Aside from the handful of reports on whole‐body MnCl2 distribution and/or contrast enhancement following intravenous 33 , 34 , 35 and intraperitoneal 32 , 36 injection, little guidance for subcutaneous MnCl2 injections exist. To the best of our knowledge, there has been no report on time‐course characterization of Mn biodistribution in bodily tissues and MRI contrast efficiency following the safest of administration routes: subcutaneous injection.
In this study, we investigate organ toxicity and time‐course profile of Mn biodistribution and Mn‐induced MRI contrast in mouse organs after a single subcutaneous injection of MnCl2.

sec.title: Experimental design
sec.p: Manganese (Mn) biodistribution and Mn‐induced T1 contrast in adult female CD‐1 mice after a single subcutaneous injection of MnCl2 were investigated at three time points following MnCl2 injection (2, 6, and 24 h) and two Mn dose levels (0.2 and 0.4 mmol/kg body weight). Mice were randomly divided into seven groups: 0.2 mmol/kg Mn dosed mice examined at 2, 6, and 24 h, 0.4 mmol/kg Mn dosed mice examined at 2, 6, and 24 h, and control mice without any treatment (n = 3 per group). In parallel, three additional groups of mice (0.2 and 0.4 mmol/kg Mn dosed mice and control mice without any treatment [n = 3 per group]) were used for histopathological assessment 2 weeks following injection.

Mice were imaged on a preclinical 3T MR scanner (MR Solutions; Guildford, United Kingdom) using T1‐weighted spoiled gradient echo (SPGR) and T1 mapping both before (baseline) and after MnCl2 injection (post‐Mn). MnCl2 solution (100 mM) was prepared by dissolving MnCl2·4H2O in Milli‐Q water and filtering through 0.22‐μm membrane. MnCl2 was injected subcutaneously after baseline MRI scan. Immediately after the post‐Mn MRI scan, mice were euthanized by cardiac puncture under deep anesthesia. Whole blood (0.5 mL) from each mouse was collected. Heart, liver, kidneys, gastrocnemius muscle, lungs, and spleen tissue were collected, weighed, and digested for Mn quantification using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP‐AES).

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: This study was approved by the University of Toronto's Animal Care Committee (protocol #20012748). All procedures were conducted in accordance with the Canadian Council on Animal Care. Six‐week‐old to 8‐week‐old female CD‐1 (n = 30) mice weighing between 20 and 25 g were purchased (Charles River Laboratories, Canada). Animals acclimatized for 1 week at the animal facility before the study began.

sec.title: Quantification of Mn content in tissue samples
sec.p: Tissue samples were weighed and fully digested by adding 0.25 to 1 mL of 70% HNO3 to cover each sample with sonication at 60°C overnight. After digestion, samples were diluted with Milli‐Q water to a final concentration of 2% HNO3 (8.5 to 35 mL final volume) and filtered through the 0.22‐μm membrane. Samples were stored at 4°C before analysis on an Optima 7300 DV ICP‐AES spectrometer at the Department of Chemistry, University of Toronto (Toronto, Canada). The Mn concentration in each sample was reported by ICP‐AES in parts per million (ppm) and converted to micromolar (uM). The total Mn content in each sample was calculated using the following equation: micromolar concentration (μM) × final sample volume (L)/tissue weight (kg).

sec.title: MRI acquisition
sec.p: MRI acquisition was performed on a preclinical 3T MR scanner (MR Solutions) as previously described. 16 Mice were induced on 5% isoflurane in 100% oxygen (1.0 L/min), maintained at 1.5%–2.0% isoflurane during the entire imaging session, and placed head‐first in a prone position inside a mouse whole‐body coil. Body temperature was maintained at 37°C using an air‐heating system built into the mouse holder. A pneumatic respiratory pillow was placed on the abdomen to monitor respiration throughout imaging and to provide respiratory gating. A three‐dimensional T1‐weighted spoiled gradient‐echo sequence was run with the following parameters: repetition time = 11 ms, echo time = 5 ms, flip angle = 30°, matrix = 256 × 128 × 24, field of view = 60 × 45 mm, slice thickness = 1.0 mm, voxel size = 0.2344 × 0.3516 × 1.0 mm3, and number of signal averaging = 4. T1 mapping was performed using a variable flip angle approach 37 with a three‐dimensional SPGR sequence: repetition time = 11 ms, echo time = 5 ms, flip angle = [2°, 3°, 10°, 20°], matrix = 256 × 128 × 24, field of view = 60 × 45 mm, slice thickness = 1.0 mm, voxel size = 0.2344 × 0.3516 × 1.0 mm3, and number of signal averaging = 4.

sec.title: MRI data analysis
sec.p: Quantitative T1 data analysis and signal‐to‐noise ratio (SNR) calculations on T1‐weighted images were performed in house using MATLAB (v2022; MathWorks, Natick, MA, USA). Organs were manually segmented by drawing regions of interest (ROIs) on T1 maps to circumscribe the relevant organs. T1 relaxation times were averaged in each ROI to arrive at a mean value. T1 values for different organs were adjusted with respect to the T1 in urine, which provided a consistent internal reference for correcting any power gain variation. SNRs on T1‐weighted images were determined by dividing the mean signal intensity of the ROI by the standard deviation of the background.

sec.title: Histological assessment
sec.p: The heart, liver, kidneys, lungs, and spleen were fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde and sent for paraffin‐embedding and sectioning at STTARR Pathology Core (University Health Network, Toronto, Canada). Sections (4‐μm thick) were stained using hematoxylin and eosin (Newcomer Supply, Middleton, WI, USA) for histological analysis. Whole‐slide scanning at 20× brightfield was performed by the Advanced Optical Microscopy Facility at the University Health Network. Slides were reviewed and assessed by a pathologist (M.H.) blinded to the groups (n = 3 per group).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: All data are represented as mean ± standard error of the mean. Analysis of variance was used to compare the difference between the two injection doses and across different time intervals. Post hoc analysis used Tukey's honestly significant difference test. Significance was reported at a p‐value of 5%.

sec.title: Mn biodistribution after subcutaneous injection of MnCl2
sec.p: To examine Mn biodistribution at different time points, absolute Mn content in mouse tissue collected at 2, 6, and 24 h following injection was measured by ICP‐AES. For both injection doses, 0.2 and 0.4 mmol Mn/kg, a single subcutaneous injection of MnCl2 resulted in increased Mn concentration in all tissues measured, including blood, heart, liver, kidneys, leg skeletal muscle, lungs, and spleen (Figure 1, Table S1). Tissue‐level Mn concentration was lower than the injected dose in all tissues except the liver (at 2 and 6 h following injection) and kidneys (at 2, 6, and 24 h following injection), which combined took up most of the administered MnCl2.

caption.p: Mn distribution in mouse tissue after subcutaneous MnCl2 injection. Mn concentration in tissue (mmol Mn/ kg tissue) was measured at 2, 6, and 24 h after a subcutaneous injection of MnCl2 at a dose of 0.2 mmol Mn/kg (A) or 0.4 mmol Mn/kg (B) body weight. Tissues were collected, digested, and analyzed by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy. Data are represented as mean ± standard error of the mean (n = 3). *Significant difference from baseline control (p < 0.05).

sec.p: Except for leg skeletal muscle, all tissues experienced peak Mn concentration at 2 h following injection. In these tissues, Mn concentration decreased by 6 h and further decreased by 24 h but remained higher than precontrast baseline levels. However, leg skeletal muscle exhibited an anomalous behavior: Muscle Mn concentration increased gradually with time, peaking at the last observed timepoint of 24 h following injection.

sec.title: Mn‐induced T1 contrast enhancement on MRI
sec.p: To investigate T1 contrast enhancement in mouse organs following MnCl2 injection, animals were imaged on a 3T MRI scanner using T1‐weighted and T1 mapping sequences. The two doses tested displayed similar trends in Mn‐induced contrast changes. Two hours after injecting 0.2 mmol/kg MnCl2, the liver, kidneys, and heart displayed SNR increases of 11.5 ± 1.5, 21.9 ± 3.7, and 6.8 ± 2.0, respectively, on T1‐weighted images, accompanying sharp T1 reductions measured on T1 maps (Figure 2). At 2 h following injection, the heart and liver showed the brightest contrast on T1‐weighted MRI (Figure 2A). Consistent with this increased contrast, quantitative analysis showed that T1 values dramatically decreased in the heart (over 2.5×) and liver (over 5×) at 2 h following injection, gradually increased thereafter but were still lower than baseline at 24 h (Figure 2B,C). The kidneys displayed bright contrast on T1‐weighted MRI at all time points following injection (data not shown), with T1 values remaining over 2× lower over the full 24 h (Figure 2B,C). In leg skeletal muscle, contrast enhancement was not obvious until 24 h following injection (Figure 2A). Muscle T1 slightly decreased (˜10%) after Mn injection and continued decreasing (1.5×) by 24 h following injection (Figure 2B,C). Comparison of the two injections doses revealed that 0.4 mmol/kg Mn extended the window of bright contrast in the heart and liver beyond 2 to 6 h (Figure 2A). Trends in T1 contrast enhancement (Figure 2) were consistent with those observed in tissue‐level Mn content (Figure 1): lower T1 values and brighter signal on T1‐weighted MRI arose from higher Mn concentration.

caption.p: Mn‐induced T1 contrast enhancement on MRI at 3 T. (A) Representative whole‐body T1‐weighted spoiled gradient‐echo images and T1 maps of healthy mice after Mn injection at different time points (2, 6, and 24 h). Quantitative analysis showing mean T1s in mouse organs injected with 0.2 mmol/kg (B) or 0.4 mmol Mn/kg (C) body weight. Lower T1 corresponds to stronger (brighter) signal on T1‐weighted MRI. Data are represented as mean ± standard error of the mean (n = 3). *Significant difference from baseline control (p < 0.05).

sec.title: Tissue‐level Mn concentration versus Mn‐induced T1 contrast
sec.p: To evaluate the Mn concentration required to generate sufficient T1 contrast on MRI, we compared the tissue‐level Mn content and Mn‐induced T1 change in the heart, liver, kidneys, and leg skeletal muscle. Tissue‐level Mn content and T1 change were significantly higher for an injection dose of 0.4 mmol/kg compared with 0.2 mmol/kg in all organs (Figure 3). In the liver, tissue‐level Mn content was significantly higher after exposure to 0.4 mmol/kg Mn compared with 0.2 mmol/kg Mn at 2 h, but a discernible difference in peak T1 contrast enhancement was absent. The kidney saw sustained significant difference in Mn content at all timepoints but no difference between the two dose levels at any timepoint; likewise, T1 contrast was not different between the two dose levels. In the heart, either 0.2 or 0.4 mmol/kg provided a significant T1 change from baseline at all times but no additional advantage from a higher dose. Uniquely, leg skeletal muscle at 0.2 mmol/kg of injected Mn required 24 h following injection to accumulate a significant T1 change, but the higher dose of 0.4 mmol/kg shortened the interval to 6 h following injection. Finally, a linear relationship between R1 (i.e. 1/T1) and Mn concentration was observed in all tissues: leg skeletal muscle (R 2 = 0.93), heart (R 2 = 0.90), kidneys (R 2 = 0.87), and liver (R 2 = 0.94) (Figure 4).

caption.p: Comparison between tissue‐level absolute Mn content and T1 contrast enhancement in mouse organs after MnCl2 injection. Mn content (mmol Mn/kg tissue) measured in the leg skeletal muscle (A), heart (B), kidneys (C), and liver (D). T1 percentage change from baseline analyzed in the leg skeletal muscle (E), heart (F), kidneys (G), and liver (H). Data are represented as mean ± standard error of the mean (n = 3). *Significant difference from baseline (p < 0.05). #Significant difference from corresponding 0.2 mmol/kg datapoint (p < 0.05).

Correlation between R1 (1/T1) and tissue absolute Mn content. Correlation graphs are shown for leg skeletal muscle (A), heart (B), kidneys (C), and liver (D). Data from three time points, two doses, and control were used to generate the correlation figures. Data are represented as mean ± standard error of the mean (n = 3).

sec.title: Histological assessment
sec.p: To evaluate systemic toxicity in mice following a single subcutaneous injection of MnCl2 at 0.2 and 0.4 mmol/kg, organs of interest collected at 2 weeks following Mn injection were stained with hematoxylin and eosin and assessed. In general, histological evaluation of liver, kidneys, lungs, heart, and spleen from Mn‐treated and untreated mice revealed no abnormalities. Representative images showing normal organ structures are displayed in Figure 5. A detailed histopathological report is provided in Table S2. Histopathological findings such as minimal mononuclear cell infiltration in the liver and minimal extramedullary hematopoiesis in the spleen are reported in Table S2; however, these were incidental or spontaneous background lesions commonly noted in mice, which is likely unrelated to Mn injections, as similar observations were also present in the untreated control mice.

caption.p: Representative histological analysis of the heart, lung, spleen, kidney, and liver of Mn‐treated and untreated mice displaying normal tissue morphology. Hematoxylin and eosin staining of mouse tissue was collected 2 weeks after subcutaneous injection of MnCl2 at 0.2 or 0.4 mmol/kg (n = 3). Mice with no treatment were used for control (n = 3). Scale bar = 50 μm.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This study was undertaken with the objective of profiling the time‐course biodistribution and T1 contrast induced by MnCl2 administered subcutaneously—a route that, in our experience, is much safer than intravenous or intraperitoneal. This safer profile is attributed to a slower release of Mn ions to the body, a more sustained whole‐body distribution, and circumventing potentially fatal outcomes from sudden spikes in blood Mn levels associated with intravenous or even intraperitoneal injection. Despite this safer profile, subcutaneous MnCl2 injection is the least common and its in vivo kinetics the least studied outside of the brain. 22 , 23 , 25 In this paper, we present, to our best knowledge, new data on the systemic biodistribution of Mn following a single, subcutaneous injection of MnCl2 in healthy mice. Our findings provide critical information for optimizing Mn injection dose and ideal imaging timepoints for different organs.

An injection dose of 0.2 mmol/kg MnCl2 was sufficient in providing substantial contrast enhancement (60%–80% decrease in T1) in the liver, kidneys, and heart on MRI at 3 T. Doubling the injection dose to 0.4 mmol/kg was necessary to achieving T1 enhancement in skeletal muscle, where the peak T1 reduction exceeded 50%. For all other tissues, doubling the dose to 0.4 mmol/kg resulted in negligible further T1 enhancement despite nearly a doubling in tissue Mn content. The fact that the tissue Mn concentration also increased significantly indicates that the plateau in T1 enhancement reflects not a physiological limit but a nonlinear relationship between 1/T1 and Mn concentration at high tissue Mn content. This nonlinear relationship arises from multiple factors, including (i) a saturation in the number water protons available to interact with the Mn ion, (ii) local susceptibility effects where T2 contrast begins offsetting T1 enhancement, and possibly (iii) altered T1 relaxivity due to binding of Mn to proteins. This nonlinear relationship is visible in the graphs of Figure 4, where a slight deviation from linearity emerges above an injection dose of 0.1 mmol/kg.

The ideal imaging timepoint was also dependent on the tissue of interest. Most tissues (i.e., heart, liver, and kidneys) reached peak contrast enhancement at 2 h following injection. Trends in contrast enhancement on MRI corroborated with ICP‐AES quantitation of tissue‐level absolute Mn content. In fact, ICP‐AES measurement of Mn concentration revealed that Mn accumulation peaked also at 2 h for tissues that were not analyzed on MRI: the lungs, blood, and spleen. Skeletal muscle in the leg was the only tissue that reached peak contrast enhancement and peak tissue‐level Mn content at 24 h following injection.

Comparison with existing literature uncovered both concordant results and discrepancies. Concordance was seen in the major organs (i.e., heart, liver, kidneys, and spleen), where literature studies of intravenous MnCl2 or radiomanganese injection also reported peak Mn content 27 , 34 , 38 and T1 contrast enhancement 34 within 2 h following injection. This temporal behavior is consistent regardless of the contrast administration route. However, discrepancies were seen in skeletal muscle. Our study showed Mn content in muscle and T1 contrast peaking at 24 h following subcutaneous injection. However, literature shows that intravenous injection of radiolabeled 52Mn resulted in peak tissue Mn concentration at 1 h, 38 and intraperitoneal administration of MnCl2 (0.1 mmol/kg) also led to peak T1 enhancement at 1 h. 32 A different study reported no change in either T1 enhancement or tissue Mn concentration in muscle 30–60 min after intravenous MnCl2 injection (0.2 mmol/kg). 35 The apparent inconsistency is expected, because low perfusion tissue like skeletal muscle will respond differently to different injection modes. Unlike high perfusion tissue such as the heart, liver, or kidneys, skeletal muscle requires a slower and more sustained injection route to overcome Mn elimination from the body and achieve adequate Mn accumulation.

With different injection routes possible for administering MnCl2 for MEMRI, the question remains as to which route to choose for the target organ of interest. If the goal is the maximize contrast in the heart, liver, and kidneys, this study and others have shown that all injection routes (i.e. intravenous, intraperitoneal, and subcutaneous) will work and will maximize contrast enhancement within the first 2 h following injection. 32 , 34 , 35 The choice ultimately depends on the operator's comfort level with different injection modes. However, if the goal is to maximize contrast in skeletal muscle, which has relatively very low perfusion, then intravenous or intraperitoneal injection will not confer significant contrast enhancement 32 , 35 —only the subcutaneous injection route is effective, as seen in this and previous studies. 13 , 14 , 39

As to why only the subcutaneous injection route was able to generate significant T1 contrast in skeletal muscle, we need to consider the pharmacokinetics of this administration mode. Injected under the skin on the mouse dorsum, the MnCl2 solution formed a visible depot that was slowly absorbed into the local blood circulation. Once in circulation, it distributed rapidly to the heart, liver, and kidneys on a time course like those reported for intravenous or intraperitoneal injections. The enhancement profile in liver is particularly interesting; here, we observed a substantial T1 enhancement that dropped to nearly zero by 24 h, when other organs still had residual enhancement. This profile can be explained by the fact that MnCl2 is eliminated primarily by the liver. The initial T1 enhancement driven by hepatocyte uptake of Mn ions quickly reverses direction as Mn is actively secreted into bile, removed from the liver, and then eliminated in feces. This biliary excretion is extremely efficient and occurs in a matter of hours. Organs that do not have this active Mn elimination mechanism, such as the heart, retained a small but significant level of Mn even at 24 h following injection. Skeletal muscle exhibited an entirely unique behavior: T1 enhancement continued past 2 h following injection and was highest at 24 h, which is not seen in either intravenous or intraperitoneal contrast administration. Because of this sustained enhancement enabled by subcutaneous contrast injection, adequate signal builds up in muscle by 24 h. A plausible explanation for the sustained contrast increase may be that because resting skeletal muscle has low perfusion and because the subcutaneous depot slowly releases MnCl2 into the circulation, there is a constant source of contrast agent that very slowly but steadily distributes in muscle. From Figure 4, we note that Mn content in muscle tissue remains low, on par with that in blood, for quite a long time, thus allowing the sustained transfer of Mn from blood to skeletal muscle without significant backflux. Another possibility for Mn accumulation is that once Mn enters skeletal myocytes, it is sequestered in the numerous mitochondria found in skeletal muscle.

The potential for Mn‐related toxicity has always been a challenge in MEMRI. It is well known that Mn accumulation in the brain can cause chronic neurodegenerative disease. 18 Heart arrest can be induced when Mn is abruptly elevated in blood. Therefore, protocols that use intravenous administration must ensure a slow infusion rate. Peak plasma levels can be reduced by adopting intraperitoneal and subcutaneous administration, which have LD50 levels of 0.73 mmol/kg 40 and 1.62 mmol/kg, 41 respectively, in mice. In literature MEMRI studies, a wide range of MnCl2 injection doses (0.05 to 1.39 mmol/kg 20 ) has been tested, with most results reported for intravenous and intraperitoneal injections. For instance, 0.35–0.70 mmol/kg (intravenous) is the reported optimal range for imaging the mouse brain, 24 and 0.2 mmol/kg is the saturation point for signal enhancement in the mouse heart (both intravenous and intraperitoneal). 30 , 31 Few reports exist for the subcutaneous route beyond the handful on imaging the mouse brain (0.16 mmol/kg 22 and 1.0 mmol/kg 23 ) and tumors in rodents (0.05 mmol/kg 13 , 14 ). To ascertain that the injection doses of 0.2 and 0.4 mmol/kg used in this study were nontoxic, histology was performed on the heart, liver, kidneys, lungs, and spleen. No abnormalities were observed 2 weeks following injection.

Several limitations of this study are noted. Only healthy female mice were investigated, but we expect negligible sex‐related differences in the transport kinetics of Mn ions. Second, contrast kinetics were not probed with more frequent intervals due to the need to reduce repeated exposure to isoflurane over a 24‐h period; future studies can probe contrast kinetics at time intervals that interleave with the ones in the current study. Third, more detailed information on toxicity can be gleaned by assessing metabolic function (e.g., alanine aminotransferase/aspartate aminotransferase test of liver function, creatinine test of kidney function). Finally, the toxicity associated with multiple injections of MnCl2 was not studied.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: In this study, the time‐course biodistribution profile of subcutaneously injected Mn was investigated in vivo in healthy mice. An injection dose of 0.2 mmol/kg provided substantial contrast enhancement in most organs, such as the heart, liver, and kidneys. Only skeletal muscle required 0.4 mmol/kg to attain a T1 reduction exceeding 50%; muscle also exhibited maximal T1 contrast at 24 h following injection instead of 2 h. No toxicity was noted on histology 2 weeks following a 0.4‐mmol/kg injection of MnCl2.

caption.p: Table S1. Mn concentrations and T1 relaxation times in mouse organs after subcutaneous MnCl2 injection.
Table S2. Histopathology assessment report of the heart, kidney, liver, lung, and spleen of Mn‐treated and untreated mice.
